Award.AwardTitle: New, GK-12 Innovating Graduate and K-12 Education in Biological Sciences

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
PROPOSAL #: 0638751
PRINCIPAL INVESTIGATOR: Luis Mota-Bravo
INSTITUTION: University of California - Irvine
TITLE: New, GK-12 Innovating Graduate and K-12 Education in Biological Sciences

The New GK-12 Innovating Graduate and K-12 Education in Biological Sciences project between the University of California Irvine and three urban school districts with predominantly underrepresented minority enrollment, focuses on life science for grades 7-12. The project's components include orientation sessions for fellows and teachers to learn about the project, a course for fellows on "Methods of Teaching Science in secondary Schools" offered by the UCI Department of Education, seminars for fellows to review and discuss new developments and experiences, workshops and summer institutes where faculty, fellows and teachers prepare inquiry-based lessons and laboratories to be presented to 7th-12th grade students, practical experience (10hrs/wk) for fellows in teaching these lessons and laboratory activities, presentations by fellows about their research, the development of a GK-12 manual on teaching practices, a handbook on mentoring and a web-based repository to disseminate practices, lessons and laboratories developed by fellows and teachers. In addition, there will be an annual symposium where fellows will present experiences. The intellectual merit of the project derives from the most current research on the incorporation of inquiry-based learning and real world connection for students. The broader impacts for this project include the integration of training and research, formative teaching experiences for UCI biology graduate students, assistance and intellectual stimulation of teachers and increasing K-12 students' performance and aptitude for science in minority-serving schools. The project proposes a sustainable relationship between the university and school districts after the life of the project by disseminating information through various media.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The GK-12 Program at the University of California, Irvine is designed to innovate graduate and K-12 education by integrating investigation and experimentation conducted by faculty and graduate students at a research institution with teaching of life sciences and biology in grades 7-12 in accordance with the California Science Content Standards.

Graduate students (GK-12 fellows) spent one year (10hrs./week) as resident scientists in local intermediate and high schools, partnering with teachers to enrich learning for K-12 students. The unique experiences interacting with local K-12 teachers gave faculty new ideas to develop effective broader impacts for their research grants. Faculty also had the opportunity to observe that GK-12 graduate students had career accomplishments comparable to the very best students in the university, showing that outreach activities improved graduate student’s communication, team-building and leadership skills. Since partner schools have a high percentage of underrepresented students, for many K-12 students, this was their first contact with a scientist.

GK-12 activities developed included, 1) orientation sessions for fellows and teachers to explain program expectations, 2) two one-week summer institutes and Saturday workshops during the academic year where faculty, GK-12 fellows and teachers prepared inquiry-based lessons and laboratories to be presented to 7th-12th grade students, 3) a weekly seminar series for GK-12 fellows to report their experiences and plan activities, 4) practical experience (10hrs/week) for GK-12 fellows in teaching lessons and laboratory activities to 7th-12th grade students at the partner schools in association with biology teachers, 5) presentations by GK-12 fellows about their research to the teachers and to the K-12 students, and 6) an annual symposium where the GK-12 fellows presented their experiences.
